instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_RIGHT: What is SMC_LID_RIGHT? SMC_LID_RIGHT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the right LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_RIGHT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.SMC_LID_R: What is SMC_LID_R? SMC_LID_R is the signal coming from the hall sensor that detects whether the laptop screen is closed or open. This must be high in order for SMC_LID to be high. SMC_LID has to be high for the machine to not fall asleep and for it to have a backlight..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
hi, this board came in, not waking up from sleep.
if i sleep the mac without closing the lid ( from apple logo top left corner, sleep ) , i can wake it from sleep.
but if i close the lid, opening the lid wont wake up the mac.
when screen is on,
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_R</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> 0v

<CHIP>U5255</CHIP> has solder ball sticking out, replaced.
hall sensor right has been replaced too ( J5260 ).
when screen is off, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is still 3.3v, should it be 0 v ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> 0v"
You have a problem with right Hall sensor.
The pull-up resistor is included on its board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message: yes, i have replaced the J5260 with its entire building, but smc lid right still 0v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message: Replaced the connector, or the Hall sensor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message: the connector with the component on top of it..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message: Check continuity between the pins of Hall sensor chip and MLB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
hall sensor chip has continuity to <CHIP>U5255</CHIP>.

any chance smc pulled down <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
smc replaced, <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_RIGHT</SIGNAL> still 0v.
problem still persist

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message: If J5260 is disconnected, tie together <RESISTOR>R5251</RESISTOR>/61.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
hi, thanks, the solution worked!
but just curious,  its like a board layer problem is it ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not waking up from sleep.
threads.message:
Isn't clear where the pull-up resistor is for these lines.
I didn't see it on the small Hall sensor boards for this machine.
It should be inside the Hall sensor chip.
You can remove <RESISTOR>R5251</RESISTOR> and see if 3V remains on its left, or right side.
